learning_outcomes.description: Understand effective communication techniques to facilitate person-centred dental practice.
Demonstrate an emerging critically reflective approach to dental practice.
Describe the anatomy of the primary and permanent dentition.
Manage and maintain a safe working environment, including principles of ergonomics.
Conduct and record a thorough patient interview to collect relevant medical, dental and social information.
Understand the ethical principles and legal responsibilities involved in the provision of person-centred dental practice.
Understand the principles of prevention of diseases in the oral cavity.

assessments.assessment_title: Tooth morphology, eruption timings & charting quiz
assessments.task_description:
This assessment takes the form of a quiz during a scheduled DENT1060 session consisting of a mix of multiple choice, true/false, matching, labelling and short answer questions. The examination will run for sixty (60) minutes and the student will be required to bring their own device for the examination. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment takes the form of a practical assessment (Objective Structured Clinical Examination) demonstrating the pre-clinical skills students have learnt in DENT1060. Students will be assessed on their performance of several specified procedures and documentation of specific protocols for relevant procedures which they have learned by completing the Pre-clinical session Learning Activities during the semester in the DENT1060 course. The assessment will be run for the duration of ninety (90) minutes and students are expected to comply to the safety standards expected in the laboratory environment.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this assessment is to evaluate the student’s pre-clinical/peer clinic performance at the interim stage and provide formative feedback to support improvement before the final clinical competence assessment at the end of semester.

Course Coordinator in consultation with the pre-clinical/peer clinic supervisory team will complete a report based on student’s clinical performance during the assessment period and quality of critical self-reflections following each session.

See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for the interim clinical practice performance task to be assessed. Detailed assessment criteria and rubrics will be provided on Blackboard.

Two domains will be assessed to an expectations met (EM) or not met (ENM) standard and mapped to the Professional competency requirements for the accreditation body for this program - The Australian Dental Council (Professional Competencies of the newly Qualified Dentist)

The domains being assessed are: 

1. Professionalism, Communication and Health Promotion 

2. Clinical Treatment and Evaluation

To achieve a pass, the criteria are as follows:

All domains are weighted equally, and the student must achieve a pass in each domain, and an overall pass.

  • A pass in each domain will involve a student receiving 3 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark in Domain 1, and no more than 3 "expectation not met" (ENM) in Domains 2. 
  • An overall pass for the report will involve a student receiving 6 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark across the 2 domains.


Please note:

  • Written feedback will be provided for any areas to improve as this is formative. Students must reflect on feedback and demonstrate improvement in the latter half of the semester.
  • Logbooks may be randomly audited by the Course Coordinator for authenticity and supervisor signatures.
  • Any significant clinical concerns related to safety will be escalated immediately via course coordinator pathways and documented and taken into consideration for the assessment outcomes.


There is no resubmission or resit available for this component. This is a formative assessment to enable the student to receive feedback on their developing clinical competency.

Any significant clinical concerns pertaining to patient safety will be escalated via clinical communication pathways to the course coordinator and recorded on this report to be considered for the assessment outcome.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Detailed marking rubric for this assessment is available on Blackboard. See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for the portfolio to be assessed for this clinical practice performance task.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this assessment is to evaluate the student’s pre-clinical and peer clinic performance for this course, at the end of the semester. Course Coordinator in consultation with the pre-clinical/peer clinic supervisory team will complete a report based on student’s pre-clinical /peer clinic performance during the assessment period and quality of critical self-reflections following each session.

Students are advised to review any feedback provided in the interim report, to improve pre-clinical/peer clinic performance, in the latter part of his course, to pass this final clinical practice performance assessment which is must pass to pass this course.

Detailed marking rubric for this assessment is available on Blackboard.

See Submission Guidelines for all components that must be submitted for this clinical practice performance task to be assessed. The submitted portfolio will be reviewed and performance in each domain considered and used to complete a report of overall performance in each domain as per the criteria and standards.

The clinical portfolio will be reviewed and performance in each domain considered and used to complete a report of overall performance in each domain.

Two domains will be assessed to an expectations met (EM) or not met (ENM) standard and mapped to the professional competency requirements for the accreditation body for this program - The Australian Dental Council (Professional Competencies of the newly Qualified Dentist)

The domains being assessed are: 

1. Professionalism, Communication and Health Promotion 

2. Clinical Treatment and Evaluation

Passing requirements:

To pass this assessment, students must achieve a pass on this summative assessment on clinical performance progress at this stage. To achieve a pass, the criteria are as follows:

All domains are weighted equally, and the student must achieve a pass in each domain, and an overall pass.

  • A pass in each domain will involve a student receiving 3 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark in Domain 1, and no more than 3 "expectation not met" (ENM) in Domain 2. 
  • An overall pass for the report will involve a student receiving 6 or fewer "expectations not met" (ENM) mark across the 2 domains.


Students must complete all required components as outlined in Submission Guidelines for the portfolio submission.

Please note:

  • Written feedback provided for any areas to improve from the interim task, must be reflected on and student should demonstrate improvement in the latter half of the semester to enable passing of this must pass task.
  • Logbooks may be randomly audited by the Course Coordinator for authenticity and supervisor signatures.
  • Any significant clinical concerns related to safety will be escalated immediately via course coordinator communication pathways and documented in the report and taken into consideration for the final assessment outcome.


In accordance withﾠPPL Assessment Procedure Section 3 Part J,ﾠsupplementary assessment will not be available for this final clinical practice performance task, as professional competencies are developed over a 13-week practicum. There is no resubmission or resit option available for this assessment either.ﾠ
assessments.submission_guidelines: The submitted portfolio must be COMPLETE in all the following respects and submitted by the published due date which will then be assessed as part of this assessment task. Any incomplete or missing information can result in a fail grade in this must pass assessment task.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture/seminar

A series of lectures or seminars (in relevant sessions for case-based learning) including, but not limited to: introduction into the dental environment, patient interviewing and examination, tooth morphology, principles of oral hygiene management. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture/seminar A series of lectures or seminars (in relevant sessions for case-based learning) including, but not limited to: introduction into the dental environment, patient interviewing and examination, tooth morphology, principles of oral hygiene management. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
UQ Extend (Online)

Online format of learning to supplement the learning content of the course. Further explanation and clarification will be provided at the beginning of the semester.


Sub-activity: self-study (online, self-directed learning)
learning_activities.topic_description: UQ Extend (Online) Online format of learning to supplement the learning content of the course. Further explanation and clarification will be provided at the beginning of the semester. Sub-activity: self-study (online, self-directed learning)

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Pre-clinic

A series of sessions in the preclinical simulation laboratory will be delivered: safe dental practice, introduction to dental equipment and examination techniques, tooth morphology based practical sessions, contemporary techniques for dental records gathering, introduction to oral hygiene concepts and products. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site. Attendance is compulsory.
learning_activities.topic_description: Pre-clinic A series of sessions in the preclinical simulation laboratory will be delivered: safe dental practice, introduction to dental equipment and examination techniques, tooth morphology based practical sessions, contemporary techniques for dental records gathering, introduction to oral hygiene concepts and products. Further detailed timetables will be available on the Blackboard course site. Attendance is compulsory.

learning_activities.topic:
Course & Peer Clinic induction

Introductory session to the DENT1060 course activities that will be delivered throughout the semester.
learning_activities.topic_description: Course & Peer Clinic induction Introductory session to the DENT1060 course activities that will be delivered throughout the semester.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(02 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Peer Clinic

Clinical activities/training sessions: students will be expected to apply their theoretical knowledge and practical skills learnt throughout the coaching and pre-clinic session into the clinical sessions, under the supervision of a dental practitioner. Further information will be clarified in the induction session. Clinical learning will be recorded in a log book throughout the semester. Attendance is compulsory

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(02 Mar - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
English Academic Communication

Workshop based learning sessions focussing on the learning, development, and interpretation of skills related to patient communication. Attendance is compulsory.
